blocks.text: **The process of defining the architecture, components, interfaces, and data flow of a software system to meet functional and non-functional requirements at scale.**

In simple words:
 ðŸ‘‰ System design is about deciding **how a system will work, what parts it will have, and how those parts will connect with each other.**
Planning all this so the school runs smoothly is like **system design.**
**System design is the process of planning and organizing the components of a system so that it functions efficiently.**
Here are the **kinds / types of system design written in simple text form (not a table):**
This type of system design shows the **overall architecture** of the system. It explains the main components, how they are connected, and how data flows between them.
This type focuses on the **internal details** of the system. It includes class design, methods, APIs, database tables, and detailed logic used by developers.
In this design, the **entire system is built as a single unit.** All features are tightly connected and run together.
The system is divided into **small, independent services,** where each service performs a specific task and communicates with others using APIs.
In this design, the **client sends requests** and the **server responds.** This is commonly used in web and mobile applications.
The system works based on **events or messages.** Components react when an event occurs, such as sending notifications.
The system is hosted on cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud, allowing easy scaling and flexibility.

blocks.heading: Difference Between High-Level Design and Low-Level Design

blocks.text: System design is the **foundation of building successful software systems.** It defines how different components of a system are structured, how they communicate, and how the system meets both **functional** and **non-functional requirements** such as performance, scalability, security, and reliability. A well-designed system ensures smooth operation, easy maintenance, and the ability to grow with increasing users and data. Overall, system design acts as a **blueprint** that guides developers in creating efficient, robust, and scalable technology solutions.
